lg.l: Dark Rangitoto, Rangitoto. Rangitoto Island, near Auckland in the North Island of Aotearoa New Zealand, is a volcanic island that was a popular recreation site for Pākehā settlers in the late nineteenth century. though it may seem
Rugged and gloomy, and barren and bare,
Hath many a spot, and many a bower
Of beauty and loveliness rare.
There are sheltered bays, where the rippling waves
With a dreamy and measured murmur creep,
Wave after wave, to the emerald strand,
To kiss it and fall asleep.
There are fairy dells, all canopied o’er
With tremulous leaves, cut sharp ‘gainst the sky;
And a mazy tangle of branches hoar
Supporting the greenery.
There are ferny nooks, where the delicate fronds
Droop from the rocks, and the banks, and the trees;
Their feathery tracery scarcely stirred
By the gentle summery breeze.
There are rocky clefts on the sea-beat shore,
All covered with lichens of every hue;
With naught seen above save the azure sky,
Naught below but the ocean blue.
There are tiny bays, where the mighty limbs
Of pohutakawas Pohutukawas. Pōhutukawa is a coastal tree that grows in the North Island of Aotearoa New Zealand. shut out the day;
Forming a temple of cool green shade
Meet for the Naiad’s play.
And where the deep, calm, crystalline depths
Reveal the secrets of mermaiden’s bowers;
Covered with sea fronds, with delicate shells
Gemming the bright ocean flowers.
Aye, there’s many a sweet, fairy spot
On dark Rangitoto that seems to bar
All that is beautiful, all that is bright,
When it is seen from afar.
So of a soul, seeming barren and bare,
Rugged and gloomy, repellant [sic] and cold,
When ‘tis approached, becomes pleasant and fair,
Showing the stamp of God’s mould.
And each human heart has its pleasant nooks,
Where love, peace, and kindly charity smile,
Though the outward form be rugged and grim
As Rangitoto’s dark isle.

body.p: Auckland, October, 1880. Auckland … 1880. Sharpe had moved to Auckland in 1866.
